quoteFirst: A series of buzzings, tappings and clinkings came over the wire, with hints of far-distant unintelligible conversation.  This continued while with agonised eyes Esther watched the hands of the big clock on the wall creep from
quoteLast: to eleven past.  Still no connection.  At last the operator, remote and chill as the top of the Tour Eiffel, informed her that there was no reply.
title: Juggernaut
author: Campbell, Alice, 1887-1976

quoteFirst: "She left here at
quoteLast: ," Jerry answered. "I felt cross about it, too. It seems as though Marjorie is always picked-out to do something for someone just about the time she has planned to have a good time herself."
title: Marjorie Dean, College Sophomore
author: Chase, Josephine, -1931

quoteFirst: "Ordered to give you this," he said, "if you made connections. If you'd been later than
quoteLast: , I was to keep dark. You've got seven minutes and a half to spare. Queer orders, but the big railroad boss, Woodbridge, give 'em to me.
title: A Court of Inquiry

quoteFirst: Greatly to Marjorie's relief, no Hortense appeared with offers of assistance, and she performed her morning toilet in peace. title: The Girl from Arizona

quoteFirst: I imagined he could not hold out long; and therefore withdrew to a little coffee-house hard by, leaving a servant at the house, with orders to come immediately, and tell me as near as he could the minute when PARTRIGE should expire: which was not above two hours after, when, looking upon my watch, I found it to be above
quoteLast: . By which it is clear that Mr. BICKERSTAFF was mistaken almost four hours in his calculation [_see_ p. 173].
title: An English Garner: Critical Essays & Literary Fragments
author: Arber, Edward, 1836-1912 [Editor]; Collins, John Churton, 1848-1908 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Seccombe, Thomas, 1866-1923 [Editor]

quoteFirst: A.M.! When we got to station at
quoteLast: she had went! No train to Ballard till night! I and subs, had to wire Bannister for money to get back on! You mis-manager--the _head-work_ you boasted of is boneheadwork! Pay the charges on this, you brainless insect! I'll send it to Butch, for you'd never show it to him if I sent it to you! Indignantly--
title: T. Haviland Hicks, Senior
author: Elderdice, James Raymond, 1889-

quoteFirst: The landlord breathed again. Having seen the end of that matter, he looked at the clock. It was now
quoteLast: . Say one hour more, if all went well. One short hour, and the agony of his suspense would be at an end.
title: Patricia at the inn
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936; Ferguson, W. B. M. (William Blair Morton), 1882-1967 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Matthews, Harry B. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: His first prediction was that Partridge would die on the 29th of March; and on the 30th a second pamphlet was published, "The accomplishment of the first of Mr. Bickerstaff's Predictions ... in a letter to a person of quality, in which a detailed account is given of Partridge's death, at
quoteLast: , by which it is clear that Mr. Bickerstaff was mistaken almost four hours in his calculation.... Whether he had been the cause of this poor man's death, as well as the predictor, may be very reasonably disputed.
title: The Tatler, Volume 1
author: Steele, Richard, Sir, 1672-1729; Addison, Joseph, 1672-1719; Aitken, George Atherton, 1860-1917 [Editor]

quoteFirst: , though he had known it three-quarters of an hour later. He thought it arrived, on the evening in question, at
quoteLast: ; but could not say certainly that the 8th of January was the night when the mail arrived at that time, though he had no doubt of it, nor had he looked at his register since that night. In short, his evidence amounted to a rough guess, which could make no impression on the Gibraltar of opposing testimony furnished by a coach full of passengers, as well as other witnesses.
title:
Ten Years Among the Mail Bags
Or, Notes from the Diary of a Special Agent of the Post-Office Department
author: Holbrook, James, 1812-1864

quoteFirst: Polly did not altogether approve of Maggie's tone, but time did press; the kitchen clock already pointed to
quoteLast: ; it was much easier to write out a programme upstairs at one's leisure in the pleasant morning-room than to carry it out in a hurry, in the hot kitchen, particularly when one's own knowledge was entirely theoretical, not practical.

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: a warning bugle is heard, to warn them that in ten minutes they must be dressed and ready. Some are kneeling at their chests, beginning the morning with prayer for help to live as in God's sight all the day. Some are hurrying on their clothes.
title:
Little Folks (September 1884)
A Magazine for the Young
author: Various

quoteFirst: "Pursuing their investigations further, the police discovered that a man wearing a big motor coat, goggles, and a cap with flap ears had taken a first-class ticket for Glasgow at Beith, which is a small place on a local branch line, in the early morning of Thursday, and had travelled to Glasgow by the
quoteLast: Glasgow being a very busy terminus, no one appears to have noticed him there, but one of the porters found a motor coat, a cap, and a pair of goggles in one of the first-class carriages on the local from Beith, and a certain Mr. Etty, who was a gentleman's outfitter in the Station Road, stated that he had a customer in his shop early on Thursday morning who purchased a tweed cap and an overcoat off the peg.
title: Unravelled Knots
author: Orczy, Emmuska Orczy, Baroness, 1865-1947
